Tallest Concrete Building

statement.p: What is the tallest building one can build with concrete wall of thickness 10\text{ cm}? Data: Density of concrete = 2,400\text{ kg/m}^3, Breaking stress of concrete compression = 20\text{ MPa}.

solution.p:
We need to compare the maximum stress in the wall, which should happen at the bottom of the wall to the breaking stress. Let w denote the thickness of the wall and h the height. Let \rho the density. Let us consider a column of area of cross-section w\times w for calculation purposes. Then, we expect stress of the weight above the bottom part
\text{Stress } = \dfrac{m g}{A} = \dfrac{\rho h w^2 g }{ w^2} = \rho h g.
We see that thickness cancels out from the calculation. Let us equate this to the breaking stress, let us denote that by B, and solve for h.
h = \dfrac{B}{\rho g}.
Now, we put numerical values in SI units to get
h = \dfrac{20\times 10^6}{ 2,400 \times 9.81 } = 850\text{ m}.

problem.title: Tension in a Crane Cable

statement.p: shows a crane supporting a load of mass m by a cable BC. The boom AB of the crane has mass M and length L. The boom makes an angle \theta with horizontal diration. The cable BC makes an angle \phi with the boom. (a) Find the tension T in the cable. (b) Find the force at the base of the boom.
Do the problem in symbols first, and then check for the following numbers. M=1,000\text{ kg}, L = 20\text{ m}, m = 4,000\text{ kg}, \theta = 30^{\circ}, \phi = 10^{\circ}.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: (a) Note that tension in cable BC is not equal to mg, the tension in the cable to which load m is attached. We will balance torque on the boom to get the tension in the cable, which we can use in the balance of force equations to obtain the force at the base of the boom.
helps us find the lever arms we need in the torque calculations. We will use counterclockwise positive.

Balancing the torque on the boom AB gives the following equation.
- M g\, \text{(AD)} - m g\, \text{(AE)} + T\, \text{(AF)} = 0,
where the lever arms are
\text{AD} = \dfrac{L}{2}\,\cos\,\theta, \text{AE} = L\,\cos\,\theta, \text{AF} = L\,\sin\,\phi.
Therefore,
T = \dfrac{Mg\cos\,\theta}{2\sin\,\phi} \left( 1 + \dfrac{2m}{M}\right).

Numerically, with
\amp M = 1000\text{ kg},\ \ m = 4000\text{ kg}, \amp \theta = 30^\circ,\ \ \phi=10^\circ,\ \ g = 9.81\text{ m/s}^2,
we get
T = 220,000\text{ N}.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(b) Let A_x and A_y be the components of the force at the base. Balancing of forces on the boom AB gives the following equations.
\amp A_x - T\,\cos(\theta-\phi) = 0, \amp A_y - Mg - mg - T\,\sin(\theta-\phi)=0,
which give us the components of the force at the base. From these we can find the magnitude and direction of he force at the base.

Numerical values give us
A_x \amp = 207,000\text{ N}, A_y \amp = 124,000\text{ N}.

problem.title: Tipping a Table

statement.p: A boy is walking on a table of half his mass and getting dangerously close to the edge. If the boy is a distance x from the edge the table will trip about the legs closest to the edge as shown in . You can assume d = L/5 and L=1.5\text{ m}.
(a) Find x in terms of the given dimensions in the figure.

(b) What should be the minimum mass of any boy relative to the mass of the table so that the table will not tip at all no matter where the boy stands? That is, if the mass of the table is M and the mass of the boy is m, give the critical m/M.

hint.p: Normal on the far side leg will be zero at the tipping point.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: shows forces on the table. Just after the tipping occurs, the left leg will no longer be in contact with the flor. Therefore, as the boy moves closer and closer to the right edge, the normal force N_1 will decrease, and at the tipping point N_1=0. Similarly, F_{s1}=0.

The torque of all fiorces about the pivot point O we get
\amp \tau_{N_2} = 0, \ \ \tau_{F_{s2}} = 0, \amp \tau_{Mg} = Mg \left(\dfrac{L}{2} - d \right), \text{ Counterclockwise}, \amp \tau_{mg} = mg \left(d-x\right), \text{ Clockwise}.
Taking the notation that Counterclockwise is positive and clockwise negative we get the following equation from the net torque on the table.
Mg \left(\dfrac{L}{2} - d \right) - mg \left(d-x\right) = 0.
Solving for x gives
x \amp = \dfrac{m d - M \left(\dfrac{L}{2} - d \right) }{m} \amp = d - \dfrac{M}{m}\left(\dfrac{L}{2} - d \right).
Using the given data,
x = 0.3 - 0.5\left(0.75 - 0.3 \right) = 0.3 - 0.225 = 0.075\text{ m} = 7.5\text{ cm}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The critical condition will correspond to x=0 since that will mean we are just at the edge of the table. This gives
d - \dfrac{M}{m}\left(\dfrac{L}{2} - d \right) = 0.
Solving this for M/m we get
\dfrac{M}{m} = \dfrac{d}{\left(\dfrac{L}{2} - d \right)}.
Therefore,
\dfrac{m}{M} = \dfrac{L}{2d} - 1 = \dfrac{5}{2}-1 = 1.5.
This says that if m/M = 1.5, the boy will tip the table if he sits at the edge, but if his mass is any less, he would not succeed.
